subject: Only run power restore on AC losses
commitMessage:
Only run power restore on AC losses

Added a meson build option that allows the customer to enable automatic
power restore policy only for AC losses where the chassis power was
on prior to a BMC reset(and off when it comes back online).

The default is set to 'false' which provides the standard behavior of
APR which is to always run APR on an BMC reboot.
If the option 'only-run-apr-on-power-loss' is 'true' then APR is only
run in the case of the chassis losing power. AC power losses trigger the
creation of a file called 'chassis@0-lost-power' that identifies an
AC power loss has occurred. This generated file can be found in the
directory '/run/openbmc/'.

Tested:
    - Verified that when built with option 'only-run-apr-on-power-loss'
      set to false(default) that APR was ran.
    - Verified that when built with option 'only-run-apr-on-power-loss'
      set to true that apr was not ran when a power loss did not occur.
    - Verified that when built with option 'only-run-apr-on-power-loss'
      set to true that apr was only ran when a power loss occured.

Jun 08 01:55:13 p10bmc phosphor-chassis-state-manager[3009]:
            The system suffered a power blackout.

root@p10bmc:/lib/systemd/system# ls /run/openbmc/
chassis@0-lost-power

Signed-off-by: Corey Hardesty <corey.hardesty@icloud.com>
Change-Id: Iac37761416d699e3a469936e00868a8d9b6dfdb1

Done
I'm trying to remember why this one was needed. The other apps here don't use it. If you remove it, do things still compile?

With the cppfs dependency added to the phosphor-discover-system-state executable this will be needed in order to compile. If I remove the dependency (and the cppfs definition) the code also compiles. The question is, is 'stdc++fs' needed in general? I will have to test it. My guess is that it will not be needed at this point
I initially added it in after viewing your downstream commit and seeing it was there, but after researching it a bit I'm fairly confident it is included in the c++17 standard. Phosphor-state-manager is compiled using c++20 and therefore the compiler linking is not needed.
Ack
Only run
Done
I'm thinking this may be better. Will test.
Done

Done

Done
This variable doesn't make much sense to me. Maybe chassisPowerLossFile or something a bit more obvious?
Done
nit: un-needed line feed here
Done
You could probably do some of your optimized fs::path using the fmt lib work here as well. Up to you though.
I was going to try and test first, but since that's been delayed I changed anyways.
Done
I don't think this compiles when the feature is enabled? You're redeclaring hostId. You should just be using the hostId set when the function starts.
Done
I was compiling with a downstream repo generated by devtool modify that did not have hostId declared. I should've still paid more attention to the repo I was using for this commit.
Hmm just noticed, this file name is concerning. Should be chassis@0-lost-power on a real system.
Ack

Good catch, I had a %d in the meson_options, as supposed to {} since we are now using fmt::format. 
Fixed, just want to retest before I make the changes upstream.
meson.build*

So I actually figured out what's going on here.
The meson setting is defined as 
'CHASSIS_LOST_POWER_FILE', '/run/openbmc/chassis@%d-lost-power')
fmt uses {} as it's formatting token.
This is a problem when building meson. 
Although I left the setting in the mesonbuild, I am creating a 
const expr CHASSIS_LOST_POWER_FILE_FMT= BASE_FILE_DIR + "obmc-chassis@{}-lost-power. This should get rid of the lack of formatting. building and testing now.

I thought I sent the above earlier,but it was living in draft purgatory. Anyways, I know why "snprintf" was used for the reasons I listed above. I left the meson file "as-is" from my previous commit. However, I declared a string for the chassis_lost_power_file, since it was essentially the only way to format with fmt.
I'm totally indifferent whichever method would be preferred. Both have their benefits.
My main concern is that there is a lot of upstream code using fmt::format which produces cleaner, nicer looking source code, but will be incompatible with meson build settings that are denoted with "%d". 
The snprintf method allows for the proper formatting to occur, but is rather ugly code IMO. 
Maybe pointing this out will prevent technical debt(or headaches) in the future.

I should've specified. This service is now attached to this target. 
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/54587
Ack

You have to treat this as it's own standalone commit. You could rebase this on top of the other change if you like. But as-is, that code needs to remain since it's not a part of what this commit is trying to do (and that other commit has not merged).
Ack
See meson.build comment. Lets not hard code the file name in two places, just make it whatever is needed in meson.build.
removed used fmt::sprintf as supposed to fmt::format.
I think you should just make this to be whatever fmt needs (i.e. the {}). We can slowly move state-manager over to using that with the other files as well since it's much cleaner code.
fmt::sprintf() is the key to clean code here.
Please use constexpr const char* here
removed
Local variables should not be in all upper case

Yeah I got myself into a wonky place tonight. I added a meson option to provide the token for the formatting, but meson does not like to work nicely with "{}" (the token fmt format uses). I'm going to figure out a way around it tomorrow. 
thus, why the wonky-ness is hard-coded atm. I know this is super ugly. Will fix.
Done

This isn't the blackout commit, it's the configurable AC loss one. Although they are related, they are different commits and it seems you've got the wires crossed here between the two. The goal of the AC loss one was to simply make it configurable on whether we could run APR on every BMC reboot or only when a blackout occurred.
got it. I guess I was trying to knockout two birds with one stone will fix.
Done

A lot of text here but what I'm really looking for is.

- Left flag at default, verified that APR was run when an AC loss was not detected
- Set flag to true, verified the APR was not run when an AC loss was not detected
- Set flag to true, verified the APR was run when AC loss was detected
Done
nit: variable names follow the chassisLostPowerFileFmt type format in OpenBMC.
Ack
nit: variable naming conventions
Ack
